When applied strategically and with international support, sanctions can create significant economic pressure that compels governments to alter policies or actions that are contrary to the interests of the imposing states.

The sustained application of economic sanctions by the international community played a critical role in isolating the regime economically and politically, ultimately contributing to the end of apartheid and the transition to democratic governance.

This outcome clearly shows that economic pressure can lead to meaningful diplomatic results.

When a country understands that aggressive or destabilizing actions will lead to economic consequences, it is more likely to act in a way that aligns with international norms. This was evident in the case of North Korea, where targeted sanctions have forced the regime to at least temporarily engage in diplomatic talks to alleviate the economic strain.

Furthermore, economic sanctions are often preferable to military intervention because they allow for a calibrated response that minimizes loss of life while still applying meaningful pressure. They can be tailored to affect key sectors of the economy or specific individuals, ensuring that the target government feels the consequences without unnecessarily harming the civilian population.

In conclusion, when designed and implemented effectively, economic sanctions are a legitimate and successful instrument of foreign policy that can lead to real and lasting changes in the behavior of target countries.
